What is the Liver?
What is the Liver?

• Makes chemicals that your body needs to stay healthy
• Makes chemicals that
your body needs to
stay healthy

• Removes waste
• Removes waste

products and other harmful substances from your blood • Guards against
products and other
harmful substances
from your blood
• Guards against

infection
infection

The Liver is a Factory
The Liver is a Factory

• Builds and converts proteins and sugars
• Builds and converts proteins and sugars

• Stores vitamins, sugars, fats and other
• Stores vitamins, sugars, fats and other

nutrients
nutrients

• Releases chemicals and nutrients into
• Releases chemicals and nutrients into

the body when needed
the body when needed

What is Hepatitis?
What is Hepatitis?

• “Hepatitis” means inflammation of the liver
• “Hepatitis” means inflammation of the liver

• Can be caused by:
• Can be caused by:

– Genetic diseases
– Genetic diseases

– Medications (including over-the-counter)
– Medications (including over-the-counter)

– Alcohol
– Alcohol

– Hepatitis viruses (A,B,C,D,E)
– Hepatitis viruses (A,B,C,D,E)

What Are Liver Enzymes?
What Are Liver Enzymes?

• Chemicals that your liver uses to do its work
• Chemicals that your liver uses to do its work

• Healthy liver:
• Healthy liver:

• Unhealthy liver:
• Unhealthy liver:

– the level of enzymes in your blood is normal
– the level of enzymes in your blood is normal

– the level of enzymes can be higher than normal
– the level of enzymes can be higher than normal

• Spread through

contaminated food
contaminated food

and water
and water

Hepatitis B

• Spread through blood-

blood contact
blood contact

• Also transmitted

through sex
through sex

Hepatitis C
Hepatitis C

• Identified in 1989 • Blood test became available in 1992
• Identified in 1989

available in 1992
page.curvetext:
• Used to be known as
• Used to be known as

“non-A, non-B” hepatitis
“non-A, non-B” hepatitis

• Spread through blood-
• Spread through blood-

to- blood contact
to- blood contact

• No vaccine available to
• No vaccine available to

prevent hepatitis C
prevent hepatitis C

Hepatitis C
Hepatitis C

• About 3 million
• About 3 million

Americans infected
Americans infected

• About 170 million infected worldwide
• About 170 million
infected worldwide

• Many do not
• Many do not

experience symptoms
experience symptoms

Hepatitis C?
page.enlisting:
• People with risk factors for hepatitis C • Those who wish to be tested

How Do People Become Infected With Hepatitis C? High Risk:
How Do People Become
Infected With Hepatitis C?
High Risk:

• Blood products
• Blood products

– Blood transfusions before 1992
– Blood transfusions before 1992

– Other blood products before 1987
– Other blood products before 1987

– Current transfusions no longer a major risk factor
– Current transfusions no longer a major risk factor

• Injection (IV) drug use – 60% of all new
• Injection (IV) drug use – 60% of all new • I n j e c t i o n
( I V )
d r u g
u s e – 6 0 %
o f
a l l
n e w

infections
infections

How Do People Become Infected With Hepatitis C? Lower Risk:
How Do People Become
Infected With Hepatitis C?
Lower Risk:

• Snorting cocaine or other drugs
• Snorting cocaine or other drugs

• Occupational exposure
• Occupational exposure

• Body piercing & acupuncture with
• Body piercing & acupuncture with

unsterilized needle
unsterilized needle

• Tattooing
• Tattooing

How Do People Become Infected With Hepatitis C? Lower Risk:
How Do People Become
Infected With Hepatitis C?
Lower Risk:

• From pregnant mother to child
• From pregnant mother to child

• Non-sexual household contacts (rare)
• Non-sexual household contacts (rare)

– Sharing razors and/or toothbrushes
– Sharing razors and/or toothbrushes

• Sexual transmission
• Sexual transmission

– Low risk in monogamous relationship
– Low risk in monogamous relationship

• Unknown
• Unknown

What About Sex?
What About Sex?

• Sexual transmission is not very likely, BUT it
• Sexual transmission is not very likely, BUT it

• If you have more than one sex partner, use
• If you have more than one sex partner, use

is still possible
is still possible

latex condoms
latex condoms

• If you have one long-term sex partner, you do
• If you have one long-term sex partner, you do

not necessarily need to change your sex habits
not necessarily need to change your sex
habits

Hepatitis C is NOT Spread By:
Hepatitis C is NOT
Spread By:

• Sneezing
• Sneezing

• Coughing
• Coughing

• Handshakes
• Handshakes

• Holding hands
• Holding hands

• Food or water
• Food or water

• Hugging
• Hugging

• Sharing drinking
• Sharing drinking

• Kissing on the cheek
• Kissing on the cheek

glasses or eating
glasses or eating

• Playing with children
• Playing with children

utensils
utensils

• Donating blood
• Donating blood

How Can You Prevent the Spread of Hepatitis C?
How Can You Prevent the
Spread of Hepatitis C?

• Cover open wounds
• Cover open wounds

• Tell people not to touch your blood
• Tell people not to touch your blood

• Clean blood spills yourself or inform others to
• Clean blood spills yourself or inform others to

use latex gloves
use latex gloves

• Dispose of needles/materials properly
• Dispose of needles/materials properly

• Do not inject drugs
• Do not inject drugs

How Can You Prevent the Spread of Hepatitis C?
How Can You Prevent the
Spread of Hepatitis C?

• Avoid sharing contaminated articles
• Avoid sharing contaminated articles

– Razors, toothbrushes, or other personal care
– Razors, toothbrushes, or other personal care

items
items

• Inform healthcare professionals/others
• Inform healthcare professionals/others

• Do not donate blood, body organs, tissues or
• Do not donate blood, body organs, tissues or

semen
semen

• Practice safe sex
• Practice safe sex

How Will You Know if You Have Hepatitis C? • Many people have no symptoms of the virus
How Will You Know if You
Have Hepatitis C?
• Many people have no symptoms of the virus

• If you do have symptoms:
• If you do have symptoms:

• Fatigue
• Fatigue

• Discomfort in the liver area
• Discomfort in the liver area

• Loss of appetite
• Loss of appetite

• Aching joints
• Aching joints

• Trouble sleeping • Depression
• Trouble sleeping • Depression

• The only way to know if you have hepatitis c
• The only way to know if you have hepatitis c

is to have a blood test
is to have a blood test

How is Hepatitis C Diagnosed?
How is Hepatitis C
Diagnosed?

• Blood testing
• Blood testing

1. Hepatitis C antibody
1. Hepatitis C antibody

test
test

2. Hepatitis C PCR
2. Hepatitis C PCR

test to find virus in blood
test to find virus in
blood

• Liver function tests
• Liver function tests

What is Your Hepatitis C Genotype?
What is Your Hepatitis C
Genotype?

6 different genotypes of hepatitis C
6 different genotypes of hepatitis C

• Like different breeds of dog
• Like different breeds of dog

• Genotype 1:
• Genotype 1:

– Most common in U.S.
– Most common in U.S.

• Genotypes 2 & 3:
• Genotypes 2 & 3:

– Less common
– Less common

page.title:
Why Should You Be Concerned About Hepatitis C? • Hepatitis C causes serious problems in some
Why Should You Be Concerned
About Hepatitis C?
• Hepatitis C causes serious problems in some
page.curvetext:
patients
patients

• Fibrosis
• Fibrosis

• Cirrhosis
• Cirrhosis

• Advanced liver disease
• Advanced liver disease

• Hepatocellular carcinoma (liver cancer)
• Hepatocellular carcinoma (liver cancer)

page.title:
Fibrosis
Fibrosis
page.curvetext:
• The beginning of scarring
• The beginning of scarring

• Caused by infection, inflammation, or injury
• Caused by infection, inflammation, or injury

• Can prevent the liver from working well
• Can prevent the liver from working well

• Can lead to permanent scarring (cirrhosis)
• Can lead to permanent scarring (cirrhosis)

page.title:
Cirrhosis
Cirrhosis
page.curvetext:
• Pronounced “sir-o-sis”
• Pronounced “sir-o-sis”

• Means “scarring of the liver”
• Means “scarring of the liver”

• At risk for liver failure and liver cancer
• At risk for liver failure and liver cancer

• Requires close medical follow-up
• Requires close medical follow-up

page.title:
Advanced Liver Disease
Advanced Liver Disease
page.curvetext:
• Fatigue
• Fatigue

• Difficulty thinking clearly or concentrating
• Difficulty thinking clearly or concentrating

• Yellow jaundice
• Yellow jaundice

• Swelling
• Swelling

• Fluid in the abdomen
• Fluid in the abdomen

• Gastrointestinal bleeding
• Gastrointestinal bleeding

• Poor blood clotting
• Poor blood clotting

page.title:
Hepatocellular Carcinoma
Hepatocellular Carcinoma
page.curvetext:
• Most common type of liver cancer
• Most common type of liver cancer

• Chronic hepatitis C increases the risk
• Chronic hepatitis C increases the risk

• Treated with surgery, medications or
• Treated with surgery, medications or

liver transplant
liver transplant

page.title:
Liver Transplant
Liver Transplant
page.curvetext:
• May be needed for patients who develop liver
• May be needed for patients who develop liver

failure or liver cancer
failure or liver cancer

• About 50% of all U.S. liver transplants result
• About 50% of all U.S. liver transplants result

from liver damage caused by hepatitis C
from liver damage caused by hepatitis C

• Most patients with hepatitis C will never need
• Most patients with hepatitis C will never need • M o s t
p a t i e n t s
w i t h
h e p a t i t i s
C
w i l l
n e v e r n e e d

a liver transplant
a liver transplant

• Blood tests

damage
damage

– Should be free of alcohol and street

scarring

few side effects

drugs

With Hepatitis C, You
Should:
page.curvetext:
• Avoid all alcohol
• Avoid all alcohol • A v o i d
a l l
a l c o h o l

• Be careful with all

medications, including over the counter and herbal medications
medications, including over
the counter and herbal
medications

providers that you have

page.title:
Hepatitis C & HIV Co-Infection
Hepatitis C & HIV Co-Infection
page.curvetext:
These viruses are spread in similar ways but are very different diseases
These viruses are spread in similar ways but are
very different diseases

HIV • Spread through blood and
HIV
• Spread through blood and

sexual contact
sexual contact

• Over time makes it hard for
• Over time makes it hard for

your body to fight off dangerous infections
your body to fight off
dangerous infections

• Can be treated BUT there is
• Can be treated BUT there is

no cure
no cure
page.enlisting:
Hepatitis C • Spread through blood only • Over time can cause
Hepatitis C
• Spread through blood only
• Over time can cause
page.curvetext:
cirrhosis and liver cancer • There is a cure BUT it’s not
cirrhosis and liver cancer
• There is a cure BUT it’s not

effective in all patients
effective in all patients

All patients with hepatitis C should be tested for HIV
All patients with hepatitis C should be tested for HIV

page.title:
Those With Hepatitis C Should
Those With Hepatitis C
Should
page.curvetext:
• Take care not to spread hepatitis C to others
• Take care not to spread hepatitis C to others

• Be vaccinated for hepatitis A and hepatitis B
• Be vaccinated for hepatitis A and hepatitis B

• Discuss treatment options with a
• Discuss treatment options with a

knowledgeable medical professional
knowledgeable medical professional

• acetaminophen (Tylenol® and others): no more than

n o

t h a n

four extra strength or six regular strength tablets per day

– Hepatitis C patients without cirrhosis may take the

recommended dose on bottle

– Hepatitis C patients with cirrhosis should NOT take

Treatment of Chronic Hepatitis C
Treatment of Chronic
Hepatitis C

page.title:
Goals of Treatment
Goals of Treatment
page.curvetext:
• Clear all the hepatitis C virus from the body
• Clear all the hepatitis C virus from the body

(“sustained response”)
(“sustained response”)

• Slow or stop damage to the liver
• Slow or stop damage to the liver

• Help decrease symptoms
• Help decrease symptoms

page.title:
What Treatment is Available?
What Treatment is
Available?
page.curvetext:
• Interferon
• Interferon

– Given by shot, usually 3 times a week
– Given by shot, usually 3 times a week

• Pegylated interferon
• Pegylated interferon

– Long-acting, taken once a week
– Long-acting, taken once a week

• Combination therapy
• Combination therapy

– Interferon (standard or pegylated) taken with
– Interferon (standard or pegylated) taken with

ribavirin
ribavirin

– Ribavirin is a pill taken twice daily
– Ribavirin is a pill taken twice daily

page.title:
Does Treatment Work?
Does Treatment Work?
page.curvetext:
• Interferon alone:
• Interferon alone:

– 10 – 15% chance of clearing the virus from the blood
– 10 – 15% chance of clearing the virus from the blood

• Interferon & ribavirin:
• Interferon & ribavirin:

– Up to 40% chance of clearing the virus
– Up to 40% chance of clearing the virus

• Pegylated interferon alone:
• Pegylated interferon alone:

– About the same as interferon & ribavirin 40%
– About the same as interferon & ribavirin 40%

• Pegylated interferon & ribavirin:
• Pegylated interferon & ribavirin:

– Up to 50% chance of clearing the virus
– Up to 50% chance of clearing the virus

page.title:
During Treatment
During Treatment
page.curvetext:
• Medications taken for either 6 or 12 months
• Medications taken for either 6 or 12 months

• Blood testing required 2 to 3 times the first
• Blood testing required 2 to 3 times the first

month, then every 4 weeks
month, then every 4 weeks

• Clinic visits every 1 month
• Clinic visits every 1 month

• Interferon must be refrigerated
• Interferon must be refrigerated

• We must have a way to contact you
• We must have a way to contact you

page.title:

Side Effects of
Interferon & Ribavirin

page.curvetext:
• Flu-like symptoms
• Flu-like symptoms

• Psychiatric symptoms
• Psychiatric symptoms

– Headache
– Headache

– Fatigue
– Fatigue

– Depression
– Depression

– Difficulty sleeping
– Difficulty sleeping

– Muscle & joint aches
– Muscle & joint aches

– Difficulty concentrating
– Difficulty concentrating

– Fever, chills
– Fever, chills

– Irritability
– Irritability

Side Effects of

• May occur from the

• May occur later in

beginning:
beginning:

– Upset stomach,

diarrhea
diarrhea

– Decreased blood
– Decreased blood

– Skin irritation from

counts
counts

shots
shots

treatment:
treatment:

– Hair loss

– Weight loss
– Weight loss

– Thyroid problems

page.title:
Disadvantages of Treatment
Disadvantages of Treatment
page.curvetext:
• Side effects
• Side effects

• Other medical conditions can be made worse
• Other medical conditions can be made worse

• Patients with severe mental health problems
• Patients with severe mental health problems

cannot be safely treated
cannot be safely treated

• Ribavirin can cause severe birth defects if
• Ribavirin can cause severe birth defects if

either parent is taking the medication
either parent is taking the medication

• Two forms of reliable birth control required
• Two forms of reliable birth control required • T w o
f o r m s
o f
r e l i a b l e
b i r t h
c o n t r o l

page.title:
Plan & Commit to Your Therapy
Plan & Commit
to Your Therapy
page.curvetext:
• Treatment can disrupt your life
• Treatment can disrupt your life

– Some patients have to stop working
– Some patients have to stop working

• Have a financial plan and a social support network in place
• Have a financial plan and a social support network in place

• Consider putting off major life events during treatment
• Consider putting off major life events during treatment

– Not taking medications on time can decrease your chance of
– Not taking medications on time can decrease your chance of

clearing the virus from your blood
clearing the virus from your blood

– Your provider will need to meet with you regularly
– Your provider will need to meet with you regularly

during your treatment
during your treatment
